West Hartford Citizens for Peace & Justice
Free Movie Night

Traces of the Trade, A Story from the Deep North

Sundance Festival Selection 2008
Katrina Browne, Producer/Director, Ebb Pod Productions


Katrina Browne discovers that her forefathers were the largest slave-trading family in US history. The film follows Browne and nine members of her family on a remarkable journey, coming face-to-face with the history and legacy of New England’s hidden enterprise. From 1769-1820, the DeWolf family trafficked in human beings, sailing ships from Bristol, RI to West Africa with rum to trade for African men, women and children. Captives were taken to DeWolf-owned plantations in Cuba . Sugar and molasses were brought from Cuba to rum distilleries in Bristol. This “Triangle Trade” drove the New England economy with slavery existing in the North for over 200 years.

Moderated Discussion will follow the film!
WHEN: Tuesday, July 7th 2009 7:00 PM, Doors Open at 6:00 PM
WHERE: St. James Episcopal Church (West Hartford Center)
1018 Farmington Avenue at Walden Street, West Hartford, CT
COST: FREE, light refreshments will be available
CONTACT: Flo Woodiel, 232-8993
For more information, tracesofthetrade.org

group.name: Beyond the Multiplex: Hartford's Indie and Foreign Film fans

item.name: Traces of the Trade, A Story from the Deep North
